text.p: These are some of the leading stories in Kuwait's press on Tuesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Crown Prince and Prime Minister Sheikh Saad al-Abdulla al- Sabah arrives in London on Monday for follow up treatment after undergoing a colon surgery in Kuwait on Saturday.
- Trade and Industry Minister Jassem al-Mudaf to visit Egypt later this month.

- Interior Minister Sheikh Mohammad Khaled al-Sabah says Kuwait will soon naturalise some stateless residents. Some 100,000 stateless people, mainly Arabs, live in the Gulf Arab state and claim Kuwaiti nationality. The government says most of them have concealed their original nationalities to seek social benefits the welfare state extends to Kuwaitis.

- Kuwait Finance House doubts the state would sell its 49 percent stake in the Islamic financial institution before a law governing operations by Islamic banks is issued. The Central Bank has said it was drafting such a law.

- Pro-democracy activists and parliamentarians form the independent Kuwait Society for the Defence of Public Funds. The non-government organisation plans to spread awarness among citizens. Parliament has a permanent committee which monitors the government's handling of public funds.
- Sierra Leone President Ahmad Tejan Kabbah arrives in Kuwait on Monday.
